channel.title: Basic Gambling Game I Made

item.title: Basic Gambling Game I Made
item.dc:creator: @Docent Limits
item.description:
@Docent wrote:

[quote=“runescape sucks, post:25, topic:542811”][quote]You have $-2,147,483,646 in your bank at the moment.
How much would you like to bet?[/quote]

Did I win?

Edit:
Also make sure whenever you read a “string” that it has no other characters except numbers. It throws a nasty little error your way.

Ex:

How much would you like to bet? 400*3 Exception in thread "main" java.util.InputMismatchException at java.util.Scanner.throwFor(Unknown Source) at java.util.Scanner.next(Unknown Source) at java.util.Scanner.nextInt(Unknown Source) at java.util.Scanner.nextInt(Unknown Source) at Snippet.handleGambling(Snippet.java:55) at Snippet.handleGambling(Snippet.java:110) at Snippet.handleGambling(Snippet.java:84) at Snippet.handleGambling(Snippet.java:67) at Snippet.handleGambling(Snippet.java:101) at Snippet.handleGambling(Snippet.java:84) at Snippet.handleGambling(Snippet.java:67) at Snippet.handleGambling(Snippet.java:110) at Snippet.handleGambling(Snippet.java:84) at Snippet.handleGambling(Snippet.java:67) at Snippet.<init>(Snippet.java:18) at Snippet.main(Snippet.java:8)

Edit2:
This dialogue doesn’t make sense:

Too bad! You have lost your bet of 4 x $50,000($200,000)

It’s saying that you did lose the bet, but it also says how much you could have won if you lost? That’s not what would happen in any other situation of gambling.[/quote]

I should’ve had instructions but in the “How much would you like to bet?” dialogue you are only supposed to type a number. Are you suggesting that I make a method that deals with that so that it won’t throw that error?

And @edit2 yeah I did mean to do that, makes me feel even worse to see how much I could’ve won.

Read full topic

item.title: Basic Gambling Game I Made
item.dc:creator: @runescape_sucks runescape sucks
item.description:
@runescape_sucks wrote:

You have $-2,147,483,646 in your bank at the moment. How much would you like to bet?

Did I win?

Edit:
Also make sure whenever you read a “string” that it has no other characters except numbers. It throws a nasty little error your way.

Ex:

How much would you like to bet? 400*3 Exception in thread "main" java.util.InputMismatchException at java.util.Scanner.throwFor(Unknown Source) at java.util.Scanner.next(Unknown Source) at java.util.Scanner.nextInt(Unknown Source) at java.util.Scanner.nextInt(Unknown Source) at Snippet.handleGambling(Snippet.java:55) at Snippet.handleGambling(Snippet.java:110) at Snippet.handleGambling(Snippet.java:84) at Snippet.handleGambling(Snippet.java:67) at Snippet.handleGambling(Snippet.java:101) at Snippet.handleGambling(Snippet.java:84) at Snippet.handleGambling(Snippet.java:67) at Snippet.handleGambling(Snippet.java:110) at Snippet.handleGambling(Snippet.java:84) at Snippet.handleGambling(Snippet.java:67) at Snippet.<init>(Snippet.java:18) at Snippet.main(Snippet.java:8)

Edit2:
This dialogue doesn’t make sense:

Too bad! You have lost your bet of 4 x $50,000($200,000)

It’s saying that you did lose the bet, but it also says how much you could have won if you lost? That’s not what would happen in any other situation of gambling.

Read full topic

item.description:
@pure2ownage wrote:

You’re all acting like I didn’t call this… OP is not serious about improving, let him be.

[quote=“Pure_, post:12, topic:542811”][quote author=Docent link=topic=661687.msg4422687#msg4422687 date=1399217925]

[quote author=Pure_ link=topic=661687.msg4422686#msg4422686 date=1399217777]

Code is horribly bad. The thing is you didn’t use common sense.

Explain
[/quote]Aside from the lack of real adherence to any convention scheme, you execute shit in your constructor (hint constructor, not executor), variable naming is dumb as is your entire structure.

This isn’t an object oriented program and how would you write it?
[/quote]I’m not going to bother to write a response, since you don’t bother to take criticism seriously. All you ever post is “THIS ISNT AN OOP!!!”. If you don’t want to adhere to OO practices then go use ASM or something.[/quote]

item.title: Basic Gambling Game I Made
item.dc:creator: @xxxtilllyxxx xxxtilllyxxx
item.description:
@xxxtilllyxxx wrote:

[quote=“Docent, post:21, topic:542811”][quote author=Tree link=topic=661687.msg4425769#msg4425769 date=1400755869]

ok you made the code work but you should really use OBJECTS because it would make manipulating the code so much easier. For example lets say you wanted to add 2 players it would be a total pain to do so with the code you provided.

But this is a very small program and it is meant to be single player. This is how I wanted it to be. I would have made it OO if I needed.

Because you should be following OOP practices 24/7. If anybody, for example US, were to read your code over, it’s hard to read, half of it is retarded, and un-needed, and it just barely works.

You’re not getting the point.
[/quote]

Then tell me what the point is.[/quote]

Read full topic

item.title: Basic Gambling Game I Made
item.dc:creator: @Nothing1 -Nothing
item.description:
@Nothing1 wrote:

One advice I could give you is that you don’t need to write handleGambling method call inside each if statement

   } else if (betInput < 1) {
                                System.out.println("You have to bet something!");
                                gambleStage = 0;
                                handleGambling(gambleStage);
                                } else {
                                theBetAmount = betInput;
                                gambleStage = 1;
                                handleGambling(gambleStage);
                                }

You can add it in the end of the if/else statements and it works the same way.

Read full topic

item.title: Basic Gambling Game I Made
item.dc:creator: @Docent Limits
item.description:
@Docent wrote:

[quote=“Ashi, post:15, topic:542811”]The code is still bad.

Snow_ did you give you some points but you still didn’t apply your own brain to the rest of the code.

if (number > 999) { myCashFixed = NumberFormat.getNumberInstance(Locale.US).format(number); } return myCashFixed;

Okay so he mentioned that. Maybe you should fix the other parts of your code that are similar such as

return false; } else { return true; } }

I’m not going to spoonfeed you on how you can make your code better, when I’m sure you are well aware of doing that yourself if you applied your brain to it.

Practice makes perfect, you’ll get there eventually :)[/quote]

Thank you! And yeah, everything I know at the moment was taught to myself (along with the occasional help from you guys). I’ll be taking AP Computer Science next year though and I’m looking forward to it!

Read full topic

return false; } else { return true; } }

item.title: Basic Gambling Game I Made
item.dc:creator: @Docent Limits
item.description:
@Docent wrote:

[quote=“Snow_, post:13, topic:542811”]Why would you write this:

if(number > 999) {
    myCashFixed = NumberFormat.getNumberInstance(Locale.US).format(number);
    return myCashFixed;
} else {
    return myCashFixed;
}

Instead of this?

if (number > 999) {
    myCashFixed = NumberFormat.getNumberInstance(Locale.US).format(number);
}
return myCashFixed;

You could also do this (ternary operator):

return number > 999 ? NumberFormat.getNumberInstance(Locale.US).format(number) : myCashFixed;

[quote]ISSUES:

  1. You have to enter the number you want to bet and multiply by 3 times before it registers for some reason (anyone help with that)[/quote]
if(inputNumber.nextInt() > theCash) {
    System.out.println("You do not have enough money to cover this bet.");
    gambleStage = 0;
    handleGambling(gambleStage);
} else if (inputNumber.nextInt() < 1) {
    System.out.println("You have to bet something!");
    gambleStage = 0;
    handleGambling(gambleStage);
} else {
    theBetAmount = inputNumber.nextInt();
    gambleStage = 1;
    handleGambling(gambleStage);
}

You call the nextInt() method three times, that’s what’s wrong. You could do this:

int number = inputNumber.nextInt();
if(number > theCash) {
    System.out.println("You do not have enough money to cover this bet.");
    gambleStage = 0;
    handleGambling(gambleStage);
} else if (number < 1) {
    System.out.println("You have to bet something!");
    gambleStage = 0;
    handleGambling(gambleStage);
} else {
    theBetAmount = number;
    gambleStage = 1;
    handleGambling(gambleStage);
}

Here you call it only one time and assign the value to ‘number’.[/quote]

Thank you snow for not being aggressive. And also thank you for pointing these issues out and helping me learn to be a more proficient programmer.

Read full topic

item.title: Basic Gambling Game I Made
item.dc:creator: @Kattoor Snow_
item.description:
@Kattoor wrote:

Why would you write this:

if(number > 999) {
    myCashFixed = NumberFormat.getNumberInstance(Locale.US).format(number);
    return myCashFixed;
} else {
    return myCashFixed;
}

Instead of this?

if (number > 999) {
    myCashFixed = NumberFormat.getNumberInstance(Locale.US).format(number);
}
return myCashFixed;

You could also do this (ternary operator):

return number > 999 ? NumberFormat.getNumberInstance(Locale.US).format(number) : myCashFixed;
ISSUES: 1. You have to enter the number you want to bet and multiply by 3 times before it registers for some reason (anyone help with that)
if(inputNumber.nextInt() > theCash) {
    System.out.println("You do not have enough money to cover this bet.");
    gambleStage = 0;
    handleGambling(gambleStage);
} else if (inputNumber.nextInt() < 1) {
    System.out.println("You have to bet something!");
    gambleStage = 0;
    handleGambling(gambleStage);
} else {
    theBetAmount = inputNumber.nextInt();
    gambleStage = 1;
    handleGambling(gambleStage);
}

You call the nextInt() method three times, that’s what’s wrong. You could do this:

int number = inputNumber.nextInt();
if(number > theCash) {
    System.out.println("You do not have enough money to cover this bet.");
    gambleStage = 0;
    handleGambling(gambleStage);
} else if (number < 1) {
    System.out.println("You have to bet something!");
    gambleStage = 0;
    handleGambling(gambleStage);
} else {
    theBetAmount = number;
    gambleStage = 1;
    handleGambling(gambleStage);
}

Here you call it only one time and assign the value to ‘number’.

Read full topic

item.title: Basic Gambling Game I Made
item.dc:creator: @Docent Limits
item.description:
@Docent wrote:

object:

Well, all class- and interface types in the package java.lang are “imported” by default. As you probably know, you don’t have to write extends Object or extends java.lang.Object, even though you can do it. The reason you don’t have to, is because it’s automatically done by the compiler for you, if you leave it out.

Oh so I don’t need to import java.lang.Exception?

Read full topic

item.title: Basic Gambling Game I Made
item.dc:creator: @Protosstribe object
item.description:
@Protosstribe wrote:

Well, all class- and interface types in the package java.lang are “imported” by default. As you probably know, you don’t have to write extends Object or extends java.lang.Object, even though you can do it. The reason you don’t have to, is because it’s automatically done by the compiler for you, if you leave it out. There are other such automatic features in the Java world. For instance an enum extends java.lang.Enum by default, so you don’t have to write that manually.

Read full topic

item.title: Basic Gambling Game I Made
item.dc:creator: @Docent Limits
item.description:
@Docent wrote:

[quote=“object, post:2, topic:542811”]1. You don’t have to import any class- or interface type from java.lang, like you do with java.lang.Exception.
2. You don’t have to use a return statement as part of a method with void as return type.
3. In your getMultiplierBonus(int) method, use a switch statement rather than an if-else statement.[/quote]

@ #2 I just realized I accidentally forgot to delete that line.

#1 I don’t get it

#3 thank you

Read full topic

item.title: Basic Gambling Game I Made
item.dc:creator: @Protosstribe object
item.description:
@Protosstribe wrote:

  1. You don’t have to import any class- or interface type from java.lang, like you do with java.lang.Exception.
  2. You don’t have to use a return statement as part of a method with void as return type, as in your main(String[]) method.
  3. In your getMultiplierBonus(int) method, use a switch statement rather than an if-else statement.

Read full topic
